description:
Something is wrong in the perfect domed city of Romdo. Between the sudden rash of murders and a virus affecting all AutoReivs-cyborg companions and workers who assist the people of Romdo - all is not right in their dome home. Detective Re-l Meyer begins to investigate, seeking answers to the weird occurrences that are happening more and more around her. But when she begins to uncover the truth, her world is turned upside down.

First, the strange immigrant Vincent Law goes missing and then a monster appears before her, shaking her to her core. But this monster is something more, something dangerous and sinister. With each question and mystery, she is led back to the creature. But what is it really? What purpose does it serve? A sign of the end or a sign of a new beginning? Whatever it is, it repeatedly brings her back to Vincent and soon, alongside his journey back to another dome world called, Mosk. As they make their way across scarred and deserted Earth, Re-l and Vincent will learn more about the monster and the "awakening"-which could be more of an ending than a beginning.

(Source: Funimation)

Note: Episode 1 received an advanced broadcast on channel WOWOW on February 5, 2006. The start date reflects the start of the regular series broadcasting.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Noir
tags.description: Stylized as a cynical crime drama with low-key visuals.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Denpa
tags.description: Works that feature themes of social dissociation, delusions, and other issues like suicide, bullying, self-isolation, paranoia, and technological necessity in daily lives. Classic iconography: telephone poles, rooftops, and trains.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Pandemic
tags.description: Prominently features a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world.

tags.name: Angels
tags.description: Prominently features spiritual beings usually represented with wings and halos and believed to be attendants of God.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

title.native: Ergo Proxy センツォン・ヒッチャーズ&アンダーテイカー

name.native: カズキス ・プラクシー

node.description:
__Place of Birth:__ Los Angeles, California, USA

An American voice director, script writer, voice actor, and former child actor. He is known for directing and writing many English language anime titles for New Generation Pictures, most notably R.O.D the TV and Hellsing. He is also co-directing BECK: Mongolian Chop Squad with Christopher Bevins for FUNimation. Jaffe has also written many articles and spoken as a guest lecturer at universities and libraries. 

(Source: Wikipedia)

Radiohead are an English alternative rock band. The band is composed of Thom Yorke (lead vocals, rhythm guitar, piano, beats), Jonny Greenwood (lead guitar, keyboard, other instruments), Ed O’Brien (guitar, backing vocals), Colin Greenwood (bass guitar) and Phil Selway (drums, percussion).  Among their most popular songs being 'Creep', 'Paranoid Android', and 'Karma Police'

Radiohead are an English alternative rock band. The band is composed of Thom Yorke (lead vocals, rhythm guitar, piano, beats), Jonny Greenwood (lead guitar, keyboard, other instruments), Ed O’Brien (guitar, backing vocals), Colin Greenwood (bass guitar) and Phil Selway (drums, percussion).  Among their most popular songs being 'Creep', 'Paranoid Android', and 'Karma Police'

Radiohead are an English alternative rock band. The band is composed of Thom Yorke (lead vocals, rhythm guitar, piano, beats), Jonny Greenwood (lead guitar, keyboard, other instruments), Ed O’Brien (guitar, backing vocals), Colin Greenwood (bass guitar) and Phil Selway (drums, percussion).  Among their most popular songs being 'Creep', 'Paranoid Android', and 'Karma Police'

Monoral is a Japanese rock band. The band consists of Anis Shimada (born on February 23, 1975) on lead vocals and guitar and Ali Morizumi (born in 1973 ) on bass and guitar.  Anis is a Japanese-Moroccan who speaks Japanese, English, French, and Arabic. He was born in London and raised in France. Ali is a Japanese-American who grew up in Tokyo. He can speak both Japanese and English fluently.

Early in his career he was highly praised for his work on [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/).

Has started to go uncredited for a lot of his work in recent years.

Started his career as an in-betweener for [Nakamura Production](https://anilist.co/studio/6658/Nakamura-Production) working on several outsourced episodes of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/Sunrise) shows. 

He had his breakthrough as animator on [Yoroiden Samurai Troopers](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) where his detailed art and animation attracted attention. He was thus selected to be character designer for the sequel, [Yoroiden Samurai Troopers Gaiden](https://anilist.co/anime/1265/), and later animation director for the [Mobile Suit Gundam F91](https://anilist.co/anime/88/) movie. 

Since then he's been heavily involved in Sunrise productions, both as animator and as character designer. Notable examples of his designs are those for [Mobile Suit Gundam Wing](https://anilist.co/anime/90/) and [Argento Soma](https://anilist.co/anime/285/).

He had his debut as a director with [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/), after which he directed the acclaimed [Ergo Proxy](https://anilist.co/anime/790/). More recent works of his include the adaptation of [Gangsta](https://anilist.co/anime/20773/), as well as the [Mobile Suit Gundam Hathaway](https://anilist.co/anime/105595/) trilogy.

__Notable works outside Anime:__

- Final Fantasy IX (Video Game, 2000) (Character Design)

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/110221339) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/815589398720847872)

He joined studio Bebow in 1982, where he was referred to by [Masayuki Yagi](https://anilist.co/staff/143406/), a senior of his at Engaru High School. [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) and Bebow’s founder [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/) were also graduates of the same school - the latter whom he would study under after joining the studio. There he made his debut as a key animator on [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/) in the following year.

He left Bebow in the mid ‘80s and joined Pack, a small studio established by [Hiroyuki Kitazume](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/). During this time he was a follower of Kitazume’s, who has said that Onda was the one capable of replicating his drawing’s the best out of the people who worked at studio Pack. After that he joined [Atelier Giga](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/) and worked there until becoming a freelancer.

His drawings feature western-influenced delicate and sharp linework with an excellent grasp on three-dimensionality. His character art in particular is highly praised both inside and outside of the industry, which he gets to brandish whenever he works as an animation supervisor. He has stated that he prefers character design and supervision work over working as an animator himself.

In 2003, he took part as a key animator on [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/)'s animated segment in Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" directed by [Kazuto Nakazawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101474/). He is also a huge fan of shoujo manga since a young age due to his older sister.

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

_Note: Not to be confused with either the [Duel Masters character designer](https://anilist.co/staff/185645/) or the [studio coordinator](https://anilist.co/staff/172956/)._

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/110221339) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/815589398720847872)

There he made his debut as a key animator on [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/) in the following year.
